revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Pauline McLynn | image = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1962|7|11}} | birth_place = [[Sligo]], [[County Sligo]], Ireland | years_active = 1988–present | occupation = Actress, author | spouse = {{marriage|Richard Cook|1997}} | website = [http://www.paulinemclynn.com/ Official website] }} '''Pauline McLynn''' (born 11 July 1962) is an Irish character actress and author. She is best known for her roles as [[Mrs Doyle]] in the [[Channel 4]] sitcom ''[[Father Ted]]'', [[List of Shameless characters#Libby Croker|Libby Croker]] in the Channel 4 comedy drama ''[[Shameless (UK TV series)|Shameless]]'', and [[List of EastEnders characters (2014)#Yvonne Cotton|Yvonne Cotton]] in the [[BBC]] soap opera ''[[EastEnders]]''.
McLynn is involved with many charities against the racing and export of greyhounds. She is a patron of Birmingham Greyhound Protection.
== Early life ==
McLynn was born in [[Sligo]], and grew up in [[Galway]].<ref name=bio>{{cite web|title=Biography|url=http://www.paulinemclynn.com/about/biography|website=paulinemclynn.com/|accessdate=11 July 2015}}</ref> She studied History of Art and Modern English at [[Trinity College, Dublin]], but was more heavily involved in the college's drama society.<ref>Aine O'Connor [http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/article754714.ece "Interview: Unexpectedly novel"], ''The Sunday Times'', 11 December 2005</ref> She graduated with an MA.<ref name=bio/>
==Career== === Acting career === Although McLynn was in her early thirties when playing Mrs Doyle, makeup was used to make her look far older to fit the character's profile. She received a [[British Comedy Award]] for her performances in 1996. The award was presented to her by [[Tony Blair]].
Other televised appearances have been in sketches on ''[[Bremner, Bird and Fortune]]'', and numerous panel shows, including ''[[Just a Minute]]'', ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', and ''[[If I Ruled the World (game show)|If I Ruled the World]]''. In 1999, she appeared in the film adaptation of ''[[Angela's Ashes (film)|Angela's Ashes]]''. She has also appeared in [[Jennifer Saunders]]' ''[[Jam & Jerusalem]]''. Between 2001 and 2003 she was recruited to play [[Mrs Doyle]] for a UK advert for online Tax returns by the [[Inland Revenue]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Allen|first1=Richard|title=Mrs Doyle in 'most annoying ad'|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/mrs-doyle-in-most-annoying-ad-6300590.html|accessdate=11 July 2015|work=London Evening Standard|date=3 January 2002}}</ref>
McLynn was critically acclaimed for her performance in the 2005 film ''[[Gypo (film)|Gypo]]'', receiving an [[Irish Film and Television Award]] nomination for Best Actress.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0572965/awards|title=Pauline McLynn – Awards & Nominations|work=IMDb|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref>
McLynn appeared in ''[[Shameless (UK TV series)|Shameless]]'', which was produced by the British broadcaster [[Channel 4]], as [[List of Shameless characters#Libby Croker|Libby Croker]]. In January 2011 it was announced that she had left the show, reportedly after a "difficult year".<ref>Ian Wylie [http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/tv_and_showbiz/s/1406079_shameless_star_pauline_mclynn_quits_show_after_difficult_year "Shameless star Pauline McLynn quits show after 'difficult year'"], ''Manchester Evening News'', 23 January 2011</ref> McLynn also played the role of Alice's mother in the [[Comedy Central (UK and Ireland)|Comedy Central]] show [[Threesome (TV series)|''Threesome'']].
McLynn played Mary Whyte in the BBC's 2013 sitcom ''[[Father Figure (TV series)|Father Figure]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/latestnews/2013/father-figure-interviews.html|title=Father Figure: interviews with Jason Byrne and Pauline McLynn|publisher=|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref>
In 2014 McLynn played the part of Evelyn, Sandra's sister in Pramface, BBC comedy. This was the episode named 'Kiss For The Camera' featured in series 3 of the programme.
On 12 May 2014, McLynn joined the cast of ''[[EastEnders]]'' as [[List of EastEnders characters (2014)#Yvonne Cotton|Yvonne Cotton]], the mother of [[List of EastEnders characters (2014)#Charlie Cotton|Charlie Cotton]] ([[Declan Bennett]]) and ex-daughter-in-law of [[Dot Cotton|Dot Branning]] ([[June Brown]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a566638/eastenders-father-ted-star-pauline-mclynn-joins-show-as-yvonne-cotton.html|title=EastEnders: Father Ted star Pauline Mclynn joins show as Yvonne Cotton|work=Digital Spy|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref> After starting as a recurring character, McLynn quickly became a regular when her character's storylines escalated. She made her final appearance on 13 January 2015, at the end of her contract. However, McLynn returned to the soap opera on 14 May 2015 for one single episode to give evidence against Dot during [[Nick Cotton]]'s ([[John Altman (actor)|John Altman]]) murder trial.
In 2017 McLynn appeared as the mother of lead character Marcella in [[Roisin Conaty]]'s E4 comedy ''[[GameFace]]'', and in April 2018 she portrayed Sister Mary in the BBC Two biopic ''Dave Allen At Peace''.
=== Writing career === McLynn is the author of ten novels: ''The Woman on the Bus'', ''Right on Time'', ''Better than a Rest'', ''Something for the Weekend'', ''Summer in the City, Bright Lights and Promises, Missing You Already, The Time is Now, Jenny Q, Stitched Up and Jenny Q, Unravelled.''
== Personal life == McLynn is married to theatrical agent Richard Cook.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2011/may/08/pauline-mclynn-happy-days-interview | work=The Guardian | first=Kate | last=Kellaway | title=Pauline McLynn: 'For Winnie the rule is: I talk therefore I am' – interview | date=8 May 2011}}</ref> She is a patron of the children's charity [[World Vision]] Ireland and is president of Friends of Innisfree Housing Association.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gray|first1=Jim|title=How Pauline's life was 'turned upside down' by her trip to Tanzanian town|url=http://www.independent.ie/regionals/sligochampion/news/how-paulines-life-was-turned-upside-down-by-her-trip-to-tanzanian-town-27555541.html|accessdate=11 July 2015|work=The Sligo Champion|date=29 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Friends of Innisfree|url=http://www.innisfree.org.uk/about-us/friends-of-innisfree/|website=innisfree.org.uk|accessdate=11 July 2015}}</ref> She is also a patron for Littlehill Animal Rescue, Sanctuary in Ireland and Birmingham Greyhound Protection.
McLynn is a fan of the [[Championship]] football team [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/FamousFansDetail/0,,10265~2098487,00.html|title=Aston Villa Famous Fans - Pauline McLynn|publisher=|accessdate=28 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150418080818/http://www.avfc.co.uk/page/FamousFansDetail/0,,10265~2098487,00.html|archivedate=18 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She says her best moment supporting Villa came in 1996 when she watched them beat [[Leeds United A.F.C|Leeds United]] in the [[Football League Cup]] final with her ''Father Ted'' co-star [[Ardal O'Hanlon]], who is a Leeds supporter.
== Awards and nominations == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Award ! Category ! Title ! Result |- | 1996 | [[British Comedy Award]] | Top TV Comedy Actress | ''[[Father Ted]]'' | Won<ref>{{cite web| title = Past Winners 1996| url = http://www.britishcomedyawards.com/past-winners/1996.aspx| publisher = britishcomedyawards.com | accessdate = 9 May 2011}}</ref> |- | 2006 | Torino International Gay & Lesbian Film Festival | Special Mention: Best Video | ''[[Gypo (film)|Gypo]]'' | Won<ref>Shared with Chloe Sirene, Paul McGann, Rula Lenska, Freddie Connor, [[Olegar Fedoro]], Tamzin Dunstone, Barry Latchford, Tom Stuart</ref> |- | 2007 | [[Irish Film and Television Award]] | Best Actress in a Lead Role in a Feature Film | ''[[Gypo (film)|Gypo]]'' | Nominated |}
